title: Elliott–Halberstam conjecture
text:
In <a href="number%20theory">number theory</a>, the Elliott–Halberstam conjecture is a <a href="conjecture">conjecture</a> about the distribution of <a href="prime%20number">prime number</a>s in <a href="arithmetic%20progression">arithmetic progression</a>s. It has many applications in <a href="sieve%20theory">sieve theory</a>. It is named for <a href="Peter%20D.%20T.%20A.%20Elliott">Peter D. T. A. Elliott</a> and <a href="Heini%20Halberstam">Heini Halberstam</a>, who stated the conjecture in 1968.
Stating the conjecture requires some notation. Let formula_1, the <a href="prime-counting%20function">prime-counting function</a>, denote the number of primes less than or equal to formula_2. This conjecture was proven for all formula_20 by <a href="Enrico%20Bombieri">Enrico Bombieri</a> and <a href="A.%20I.%20Vinogradov">A. I. Vinogradov</a> (the <a href="Bombieri%E2%80%93Vinogradov%20theorem">Bombieri–Vinogradov theorem</a>, sometimes known simply as "Bombieri's theorem"); this result is already quite useful, being an averaged form of the <a href="generalized%20Riemann%20hypothesis">generalized Riemann hypothesis</a>. It is known that the conjecture fails at the endpoint formula_21.
The Elliott–Halberstam conjecture has several consequences. One striking one is the result announced by <a href="Dan%20Goldston">Dan Goldston</a>, <a href="J%C3%A1nos%20Pintz">János Pintz</a>, and <a href="Cem%20Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m">Cem Yıldırım</a>, which shows (assuming this conjecture) that there are infinitely many pairs of primes which differ by at most 16. In November 2013, <a href="James%20Maynard%20%28mathematician%29">James Maynard</a> showed that subject to the Elliott–Halberstam conjecture, one can show the existence of infinitely many pairs of consecutive primes that differ by at most 12. In August 2014, <a href="Polymath%20Project">Polymath</a> group showed that subject to the <a href="generalized%20Elliott%E2%80%93Halberstam%20conjecture">generalized Elliott–Halberstam conjecture</a>, one can show the existence of infinitely many pairs of consecutive primes that differ by at most 6. Without assuming any form of the conjecture, the lowest proven bound is 246.
